message.raw:
Add target_cycle_time and cycle_time_delay_after_programming kwargs to stop()

Document them with a docstring to stop().

Add a top-level group to the HDF5 file, shot_properties, for saving settings
that pertain to shots as a whole. Save the two cycle_time settings there.

values.message: Correct some docstring typos

message.raw:
Make wait monitors optional.

It will be up to individual devices whether to raise an exception if they are
asked to do analog input and require a wait monitor when one is not present,
or if they require a wait monitor for any other purpose.

If using a wait monitor, make the use of a timeout device optional.

Add a detailed docstring for WaitMonitor

message.raw:
Fixed bug in gated clocks feature

We previously only checked that instructions on clocklines were not too close together for the clock limit (i.e. was an instruction on clockline A too close to the next instruction on clockline A, and was instruction B too close to the next instruction on clockline B). However, this does not catch the case where an instruction on clockline B is close to an instruction on clockline A, thus forcing the pulse on clockline A to be shorter than it would otherwise.

This case is now caught in the below patch.
message.html:
Fixed bug in gated clocks feature

We previously only checked that instructions on clocklines were not too close together for the clock limit (i.e. was an instruction on clockline A too close to the next instruction on clockline A, and was instruction B too close to the next instruction on clockline B). However, this does not catch the case where an instruction on clockline B is close to an instruction on clockline A, thus forcing the pulse on clockline A to be shorter than it would otherwise.

This case is now caught in the below patch.

However, this does not catch the case where an instruction on clockline B is close to an instruction on clockline A, thus forcing the pulse on clockline A to be shorter than it would otherwise.

We previously only checked that instructions on clocklines were not too close together for the clock limit (i.e. was an instruction on clockline A too close to the next instruction on clockline A, and was instruction B too close to the next instruction on clockline B). However, this does not catch the case where an instruction on clockline B is close to an instruction on clockline A, thus forcing the pulse on clockline A to be shorter than it would otherwise.

This case is now caught in the below patch.

message.raw:
Allow setting marker colors using strings such as 'red' or '#ff8g80'.
If no colour is set, save the color as (-1, -1, -1), to distinguish 'no colour
set' from black. This way, actually setting the colour to black can be done,
whereas the BLACS progress bar can fall back to default colours if no colour has
been set (right now it uses default colours if it encounters black, precluding
one from actually using black).

If BLACS and runviewer are not updated after this change, they will encounter
colours that are (-1, -1, -1). They will not break, but they will print a
warning from Qt and will treat the colour as black. So this is fairly backward
compatible - the only visible consequence is the BLACS progress bar will be black
instead of blue for markers with no colour set, until BLACS is updated to be
aware of the change.

Corresponding changes to BLACS and runviewer will make them aware of the
distinction between black and 'unset'.

Allow setting marker colors using strings such as 'red' or '#ff8g80'.
If no colour is set, save the color as (-1, -1, -1), to distinguish 'no colour
set' from black. This way, actually setting the colour to black can be done,

instead of blue for markers with no colour set, until BLACS is updated to be
aware of the change.

Corresponding changes to BLACS and runviewer will make them aware of the
distinction between black and 'unset'.

message.raw:
Changes to the structure of the DDS device class for the implementation of labscript_devices pull request 62.
Renamed class DDS to DDSQuantity, which can be subclassed to create more customized subclasses for devices with extra functionality (e.g. PulseBlasters).
Created new stub class DDS to take the place of the previous DDS class, for general use by most devices.
Added keyword argument to allow the calling of parent_device.add_device() to be turned off to allow flexibility in subclasses (see PulseBlasterDDS subclass).

message.raw:
Move trigger validity checks into TriggerableDevice from the Camera class.

They are applicable to all triggerable devices, not just the Camera, so
it avoids code duplication to have them here. Devices requesting triggers at
particular times should call self.trigger() instead of self.trigger_device.trigger(),
in order to take advantage of the checks.

This was motivated by me implementing a new camera class, this way I will
not be duplicating code.

I'll make a separate change to the Camera class in labscript_devices,
removing the code from there and depending on this version of labscript.
It is harmless having the checks be in both places, the checks in
labscript will not find any triggers to throw errors about until device classes
are updated to call self.trigger() instead of self.trigger_device.trigger().

Spurious errors could be thrown if some devices called self.trigger() and others
called self.trigger_device.trigger(), so all the devices in labscript_devices
will be updated at once (I think it's just the camera, but I'll check).

I'll make a separate change to the Camera class in labscript_devices,

It is harmless having the checks be in both places, the checks in

Spurious errors could be thrown if some devices called self.trigger() and others

will be updated at once (I think it's just the camera, but I'll check).

Move trigger validity checks into TriggerableDevice from the Camera class.

They are applicable to all triggerable devices, not just the Camera, so
it avoids code duplication to have them here. Devices requesting triggers at

values.message:
Move trigger validity checks into TriggerableDevice from the Camera class.

They are applicable to all triggerable devices, not just the Camera, so
it avoids code duplication to have them here. Devices requesting triggers at
particular times should call self.trigger() instead of self.trigger_device.trigger(),
in order to take advantage of the checks.

This was motivated by me implementing a new camera class, this way I will
not be duplicating code.

I'll make a separate change to the Camera class in labscript_devices,
removing the code from there and depending on this version of labscript.
It is harmless having the checks be in both places, the checks in
labscript will not find any triggers to throw errors about until device classes
are updated to call self.trigger() instead of self.trigger_device.trigger().

Spurious errors could be thrown if some devices called self.trigger() and others
called self.trigger_device.trigger(), so all the devices in labscript_devices
will be updated at once (I think it's just the camera, but I'll check).

message.raw:
Slightly modified semantics of set_passed_properties.

* non-keyword arguments can now be saved as well as keyword arguments.
* If an instance attribute exists with the same name as an argument after
  `__init__` runs, its value will be saved instead.
message.html:
Slightly modified semantics of set_passed_properties.

  • non-keyword arguments can now be saved as well as keyword arguments.
  • If an instance attribute exists with the same name as an argument after
    __init__ runs, its value will be saved instead.

  `__init__` runs, its value will be saved instead.

message.raw:
Allow parent of IntermediateDevice to be None.
This is useful for devices that can operate in static or buffered mode
depending on instantiation settings.

Use case: some DAQmx devices have only static outputs, and even those that
have buffered outputs can be operated in static mode without a clock. It doesn't make
a lot of sense to change what type of class they are based on how they are
configured (e.g. with instantiation arguments), so I figure the least odd thing
to do is just extend IntermediateDevice's definition into devices that *might*
be clocked, but don't necessarily have to be.

depending on instantiation settings.

message.raw:
If the wait monitor acquisition device has a 'wait_monitor_minimum_pulse_width'
attribute indicating the shortest pulse the wait monitor acquisition device can
measure, then have labscript not produce wait monitor pulses shorter than this.

message.raw:
Permit the trigger slope to be specified (rising or falling) for the timeout
trigger device of a wait (timeout_connection). This is distinct from the
trigger_edge_type of the WaitMonitor.connection, which is by default rising,
unless specificied otherwise in the kwargs of WaitMonitor.__init__.
This is useful for PulseBlaster devies trigger off a falling edge.

This is useful for PulseBlaster devies trigger off a falling edge.

message.raw:
Provide start_order and stop_order for devices, to specify what order
BLACS should transition them to buffered mode and static mode respectively.
Allows any integer, default is zero.
If specified on a device without a BLACS_connection attribute, a TypeError is
raised during compilation.
start_order and stop_order are saved as device_properties, and thus can vary
from shot-to-shot without a connection table recompilation.

At a later date (labscript 3?), devices connected directly to BLACS will
probably be a subclass of a BLACSDevice mixin class or something like that,
at which point we can make only these classes have the keyword arguments in the
first place. For the moment however this seems like a workable implementation.

values.message:
Provide start_order and stop_order for devices, to specify what order
BLACS should transition them to buffered mode and static mode respectively.
Allows any integer, default is zero.
If specified on a device without a BLACS_connection attribute, a TypeError is
raised during compilation.
start_order and stop_order are saved as device_properties, and thus can vary
from shot-to-shot without a connection table recompilation.

At a later date (labscript 3?), devices connected directly to BLACS will
probably be a subclass of a BLACSDevice mixin class or something like that,
at which point we can make only these classes have the keyword arguments in the
first place. For the moment however this seems like a workable implementation.

message.raw:
Modified RemoteBLACS and SecondaryControlSystem classes to use a device hierarchy to represent network connections, allowing a flatter interface for use with Devices (now passwed in as optional keyword arguments worker and gui)

Other relevant points:
* worker and gui kwargs are only allowed if the device has a BLACS_connection saved (check done at connection table write stage)
* we instantiate an object representing the "Primary BLACS" instance which is stored in compiler, and is the parent of all remote connections
* the worker and gui kwargs exist in connection_table_properties for relevant devices (if missing, assume primary BLACS) and store the name of the "device" that represents the remote connection. This negates the need for separate classes for remote workers and remote GUIs
* the specified worker must be equal to, or a child of, the gui (if gui=None, then gui is set to the primary BLACS instance, and all remote devices are children of this)
* the
* As before, RemoteBLACS implies that the GUI/worker will be launched/managed/restarted by the forthcoming zprocess command server where as SecondaryControlSystem is for standalone applications that must be managed by the user (in a similar vain to how we treat BIAS)
message.html:
Modified RemoteBLACS and SecondaryControlSystem classes to use a device hierarchy to represent network connections, allowing a flatter interface for use with Devices (now passwed in as optional keyword arguments worker and gui)

Other relevant points:
worker and gui kwargs are only allowed if the device has a BLACS_connection saved (check done at connection table write stage)
 we instantiate an object representing the "Primary BLACS" instance which is stored in compiler, and is the parent of all remote connections
the worker and gui kwargs exist in connection_table_properties for relevant devices (if missing, assume primary BLACS) and store the name of the "device" that represents the remote connection. This negates the need for separate classes for remote workers and remote GUIs
 the specified worker must be equal to, or a child of, the gui (if gui=None, then gui is set to the primary BLACS instance, and all remote devices are children of this)
the
 As before, RemoteBLACS implies that the GUI/worker will be launched/managed/restarted by the forthcoming zprocess command server where as SecondaryControlSystem is for standalone applications that must be managed by the user (in a similar vain to how we treat BIAS)

summary.raw:
Modified RemoteBLACS and SecondaryControlSystem classes to use a device hierarchy to represent network connections, allowing a flatter interface for use with Devices (now passwed in as optional keyword arguments worker and gui)

Other relevant points:
* worker and gui kwargs are only allowed if the device has a BLACS_connection saved (check done at connection table write stage)
* we instantiate an object representing the "Primary BLACS" instance which is stored in compiler, and is the parent of all remote connections
* the worker and gui kwargs exist in connection_table_properties for relevant devices (if missing, assume primary BLACS) and store the name of the "device" that represents the remote connection. This negates the need for separate classes for remote workers and remote GUIs
* the specified worker must be equal to, or a child of, the gui (if gui=None, then gui is set to the primary BLACS instance, and all remote devices are children of this)
* the
* As before, RemoteBLACS implies that the GUI/worker will be launched/managed/restarted by the forthcoming zprocess command server where as SecondaryControlSystem is for standalone applications that must be managed by the user (in a similar vain to how we treat BIAS)
